historically, politically, and economically.

The region is an economic powerhouse beyond even the

in South China. If this area were a country, its population of 156 million (2010 census) would be 8th largest in the world (after Nigeria, ahead of Bangladesh), and its GDP of over $15 billion would be 12th (after Canada, ahead of Australia). The area has many millions of migrants from poorer provinces of China — especially

— who come mainly to seek work.

The main cities of the region include:

On the trail of Marco Polo
the city is beyond dispute the finest and the noblest in the world

(Jiangsu Province), capital of China under several dynasties, of the Tai Ping Kingdom in the 19th century, and of the Republic of China 1912-1949. Its history goes back to several hundred BCE and for most of that time it has been one of the most important cities in China.
(Zhejiang Province), a major trading port in the tea clipper era, still an important port and industrial city

, unlike other cities in the area, did not become very important until the 19th century, though some neighborhoods date back much further. Relics of the city's heyday — 1840s to 1930s — abound, a fascinating mixture of East and West. Today, Shanghai is the hub of the region and the financial and fashion center of China.

(Jiangsu Province), old city of canals and gardens, capital of one of the three states in the Three Kingdoms Period, 220-280 CE. Later it became a retirement destination for officials, many of whom built classical Chinese gardens.
(Zhejiang Province), a busy seaport and industrial city
(Jiangsu Province), an old trading city on the Yangtze, center of the salt trade for centuries.
Heaven has paradise, but Earth has Hangzhou and Suzhou.

Both cities are among the most-visited destinations for Chinese tourists, and also major destinations for international tourism. Their main attractions — the classical gardens of Suzhou and West Lake in the center of Hangzhou — are on the

.

All these cities are now quite modern, heavily industrialised, very busy, and still expanding.
Some scenic areas in the region provide a somewhat rural escape for city dwellers:

value: is a large lake in the center of the region, right on the Jiangsu-Zhejiang border.
is an island near Ningbo, a national park with an important Buddhist temple.

Much of the region is flat Yangtze Delta terrain and has

, the traditional market towns for agricultural areas and now tourist attractions. All have picturesque canals with old houses along them and many bridges, and many are set up to accommodate tourists.

value: 绍兴, is the largest of these, a city of about half a million. It attracts many Chinese tourists to whom it is famous as the "town of fish and rice", an expression indicating prosperity.
is close to downtown and can be reached by metro.
are further out and need a bus ride.
, an historic town south-west of Shanghai. The final scene from Mission Impossible 3 was filmed here.
乌镇 is close to Hangzhou and makes a good stop en route between Shanghai and Hangzhou. There are buses from Shanghai Stadium.

province) has over 60,000 hectares (about 235 square miles) of bamboo groves and 40 different species of bamboo.
were the great cities of this region; both have been the capital of China, Nanjing under several different regimes.

was another important city, famous for its gardens, canals and silk. It was the capital of the Kingdom of Wu at a time when China was divided.

In the 19th century, China lost two "Opium Wars" to foreign powers, and was forced to open certain
to foreign trade in the treaties that ended those wars.

were opened in the 1840s, after the first war; both developed very rapidly after that. Until then, Shanghai was not a particularly significant town, though it did enjoy a strategic position at the mouth of the great Yangtze River, but by the early 20th century Shanghai became one of the world's richest and wildest cities. After the second war in the 1860s, cities further inland up the Yangtze were opened  —

links. More of everything is under construction; cranes are visible everywhere. The entire region is a hive of industry, one of the most prosperous in China. It is a magnet for migrants from poorer regions who come here in droves seeking work.

is the lingua franca; nearly everyone can speak it except some of the elderly. As elsewhere in China, English is not widespread but some people speak it quite well.

The region does have its own language group, called

. This is a populous region and the number of Wu speakers is large. The language is also referred to as Shanghai dialect or Shanghainese, though that is not strictly accurate. There are local variants of Wu; the prestige dialect is that of
(an older city, capital of the Kingdom of Wu centuries back, and home to many scholars),
that of Shanghai. Wu is spoken over quite a broad area, including Shanghai, most of
and even a few places in
. Dialects of Mandarin are spoken natively in northern Jiangsu, such as the area around
Perhaps the commonest way to reach the area is to fly to
. There are two airports in the city with
as a major international airport with connections all over the world and Hongqiao that is closer to the centre and handles mainly domestic flights, plus some to nearby countries such as

. Buses and the Metro line 2 connect the two, taking about an hour. There are also direct buses from Pudong airport to major cities in the region; see the city articles for details.

Shanghai Metro Line 2 (the main East-West line through downtown) goes to both airports and to the new Hongqiao train station right next to Hongqiao airport, which has

to many places in the region and beyond. This is not a convenient way to get between the airports if you have a lot of luggage, because you need to change trains once. On the other hand, if you are travelling light and have a bit of time to spare, you can easily jump off somewhere in the middle for a quick look at central Shanghai.
